channel.title: NPR Topics: National
channel.description: NPR coverage of national news, U.S. politics, elections, business, arts, culture, health and science, and technology. Subscribe to the NPR Nation RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: NASA eyes March 6 to launch 4 astronauts to the moon on Artemis II mission
item.description: The four astronauts heading to the moon for the lunar fly-by are the first humans to venture there since 1972. The ten-day mission will travel more than 600,000 miles.
item.content:encoded:
The four astronauts heading to the moon for the lunar fly-by are the first humans to venture there since 1972. The ten-day mission will travel more than 600,000 miles.

(Image credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo)
item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: On pins and needles: Why Olympians pass the time knitting
item.description: A number of Olympic athletes have turned to knitting during the heat of the Games, including Ben Ogden, who this week became the most decorated American male Olympic cross-country skier.
item.content:encoded:
Right: Bronze medallist USA's Jessie Diggins celebrates on the podium for the women's cross-country 10km. Both Olympians knit during their downtime between events.'/>

A number of Olympic athletes have turned to knitting during the heat of the Games, including Ben Ogden, who this week became the most decorated American male Olympic cross-country skier.

(Image credit: Anne-Christine Poujoulat)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: U.K. considers cutting ex-Prince Andrew from line of succession over his Epstein ties
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the British former prince, is being investigated on suspicion of misconduct in having shared confidential trade information with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
item.content:encoded:
Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the British former prince, is being investigated on suspicion of misconduct in having shared confidential trade information with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

(Image credit: Kin Cheung)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Facing a mental health crisis, an NJ school pulled a beloved novel from English class
item.description: Junot Díaz's The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao was removed from an English class at the public school. PEN America says it's part of a trend of scrubbing literature dealing with uncomfortable topics.
item.content:encoded:
The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao from the curriculum of a high-level English class at Columbia High School in Maplewood, N.J., in response to a mental health crisis.'/>

Junot Díaz's The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao was removed from an English class at the public school. PEN America says it's part of a trend of scrubbing literature dealing with uncomfortable topics.

(Image credit: Anastasia Tsioulcas)
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Supreme Court strikes down Trump's tariffs
item.description: The 6-3 ruling is a major blow to the president's signature economic policy.
item.content:encoded:
The 6-3 ruling is a major blow to the president's signature economic policy.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: Scientists worry about lasting damage from Potomac sewage spill
item.description: Drinking water around the District of Columbia hasn't been contaminated. But scientists say the environmental damage could be severe.
item.content:encoded:
Drinking water around the District of Columbia hasn't been contaminated. But scientists say the environmental damage could be severe.

(Image credit: Nathan Ellgren)
item.dc:creator: Michael Copley

item.title: U.S. Commission on Fine Arts approves Trump's White House ballroom plan
item.description: The U.S. Commission on Fine Arts, which is packed with President Trump's allies, voted to approve the new White House ballroom project pursued by Trump.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. Commission on Fine Arts, which is packed with President Trump's allies, voted to approve the new White House ballroom project pursued by Trump.
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith

item.title: Los Angeles wildfires survivors say they're being denied aid for political reasons
item.description: Survivors of the deadly Los Angeles wildfires say they're in the crosshairs of the White House v. California political battle over aid. It's making it difficult for some to recover let alone rebuild.
item.content:encoded: Survivors of the deadly Los Angeles wildfires say they're in the crosshairs of the White House v. California political battle over aid. It's making it difficult for some to recover let alone rebuild.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Siegler

item.title: What worked and what didn't with a cellphone ban at a Kentucky school
item.description: Keeping students off their devices is the new norm in many schools. We talked to students and educators at one Kentucky school to see how it's working.
item.content:encoded:
Keeping students off their devices is the new norm in many schools. We talked to students and educators at one Kentucky school to see how it's working.

(Image credit: Lydia Schweickart for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Sequoia Carrillo

item.title: U.S. figure skater Alysa Liu said she didn't care if she medaled. She won gold
item.description: Liu is the first American woman to win an individual figure skating gold medal since Sarah Hughes in 2002.
item.content:encoded:
Liu is the first American woman to win an individual figure skating gold medal since Sarah Hughes in 2002.

(Image credit: Jamie Squire)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman
